meeting_annotations.speaker: David Gator Kwabi
meeting_annotations.transcript: that lie at the nexus of you know like thinking about sort of geography and like location specific um things that are location specific that we could leverage to do CO2 capture and also thinking about existing industries and and scale so thinking about solutions that sort of um straddle those three requirements if you like.

meeting_annotations.speaker: David Gator Kwabi
meeting_annotations.transcript: one example of this and this is not my idea um that had been proposed previously to think about sort of the chloral industry um and thinking about you know so so there you're making you're taking sea water which you know addresses the issue of scale you're making hydrogen and chlorine and sodium hydroxide you know in principle if you could power that process renewably uh take the hydrogen and chlorine right feed it into a fuel cell.

meeting_annotations.speaker: David Gator Kwabi
meeting_annotations.transcript: and and you know so you could think about sort of trying to take this process which is already established and integrating it in a way that you know gets at the problem of CO2 capture and the problem of scale so if you could locate such as project in a region where there's you know you know close to the coast and there's abundant sea water and insulation is really high in principle you could you could work out something maybe even put together like a demo plant in a way that's that might be logistically easier to do than you know what like uh climb works I think they just announced that they they did their first they have a sort of their first demo plant up up and running so I think might be interesting to think about solutions like that which incorporate scale and industries that you know already exist like you know 35 million tons in terms of the the chloral industry so leveraging those for air capture.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Greeshma Gadikota
meeting_annotations.transcript: So David I have two follow up comments to that my my thoughts in this space are that if you have to go from CO2 to product and if there is money to be made in that space you're going to get a lot of investors interested particularly if you can add on some 45Q credits to that so in many ways if there is the right market environment and the right policy environment and if you come up with innovation innovative chemistries and processes to do that the CO2 conversion problem might actually be handled by the market quite effectively the question then becomes a CO2 storage market which is you know who's going to store because then we're always thinking about the product that we want to produce to offset that cost right and typically with CO2 storage the product has been more hydrocarbons which is probably not the best thing if you're interested in putting the carbon back into the ground so then the question becomes who's going to take ownership of that CO2 that's stored and so for that reason in addition to geologic carbon storage there's a lot of interest in exploring aspects like mineralization right where you know if you can take that CO2 and in an accelerated manner convert that into a relatively solid carbonate you have the option of storing it you have the option of reusing it and then the question becomes what innovative chemistries can we come up with to reduce that cost down further and further till they become competitive because if you do that then there is a market that can be realized because there is you can store it but then you can still use the stored CO2 again the question is market size right we'll end up producing so much carbonate that there will be no value for carbonate.

meeting_annotations.speaker: David Gator Kwabi
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I mean this gets at the sort of the discussion I think that that was had in the very beginning of this sort of conference in terms of you know do we emphasize or really push uh you know thinking about market incentives and you know mechanisms for getting you know industry involved or interested or do you hope that you know policy there's going to be policy incentives to to capture carbon and even if the market doesn't exist and I suppose you know one could if there are ways to look at you know use these products of accelerated weathering in some sort of industry then that sweetens the deal for both for both parties but anyway I just sort of throwing that out there as a potential path forward the specifics are really going to matter as usual.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Andrew Teixeira
meeting_annotations.transcript: just going to say getting back to even what like Chris said that one one solution is not going to solve everything uh so even if we're only targeting that one small fraction when then we saturate the carbonate market you know that becomes that one small slice of the the overall solution the market will decide you know it's not economical to build another carbonate production plant.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ellen B. Stechel
meeting_annotations.transcript: I I'd like to bring the conversation back if I could to something Christian said she asked um a question and and then we shifted directions which was I mean was a really good conversation but uh Christian asked the question about coal plants and um you know coal plants have the highest concentration but at least in the US uh coal plants are closing very fast and almost all of them will be closed um you know within uh the next two decades for sure so the question I would like to ask is does it make sense to focus on capture from coal plants or should for stationary sources think more in terms of natural gas plants which will live longer um cement plants um ammonia plants you know some other um uh point sources uh or or for ammonia should we only be focusing on renewable and say those are going to go away um so that that's sort of my question to the group is you know which point sources might be important.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Andrew Teixeira
meeting_annotations.transcript: I would also add to it one of the ones I've been interested in for a while now is waste to energy uh or waste to uh chemicals or anything and that's another distributed resource that we're just accumulating which has a large carbon chain and most of the world ends up incinerating that uh and obviously incineration there that's another point source that we could capture um and I would actually just to connect this back to something I said at the beginning was as question kind of direct air versus point source and I think I ruffled some feathers by kind of questioning the need for not the need for direct air but the magnitude um and I think what I what I wanted to get at was not that we don't need it because it's it's a clear need it was more so um are there ways of taking sources that are traditionally dilute and concentrating them to make intentionally make a point source um and this might be controversial I don't know but saying instead of landfilling waste we actually purposefully incinerate it to drive it down to carbonates or instead of I mean similar to bex um taking intentionally growing biomass to drive to a sequestered source later on and that was just in the spirit of I guess um what the topic for this session was was beyond direct air so I was just kind of curious about the thoughts there.

meeting_annotations.transcript: So Andrew and Ellen I think you're um I think you raised a very important point which is something that I've just kind of scratching the surface on which is the trajectory for defossilization and the trajectory for decarbonization right so with defossilization you know last year we were lucky enough to get funded on a project where we were looking at electrochemically making the precursors for cement that effectively limits CO2 emissions from the initial processes that are very very CO2 emitting in construction companies so that's a defossilization strategy.
